description: From Middle English hepe, from Old English hƒìap, from Proto-West Germanic *haup, from Proto-Germanic *haupaz (compare Dutch hoop, German Low German Hupen, German Haufen), from Proto-Indo-European *koupos (‚Äúhill‚Äù) (compare Lithuanian ka≈©pas, Albanian qipi (‚Äústack‚Äù), Avestan ê¨êê¨Çê¨üê¨Ä‚Äé (k√•fa)).

entries.meaning: (possibly offensive) very; representing broken English stereotypically or comically attributed to Native Americans
examples: We are all familiar with the stereotyped broken English which writers of Western stories, comic strips, and similar literature put into the mouths of Indians: 'me heap big chief', 'you like um fire water', and so forth.

entries.meaning: A crowd; a throng; a multitude or great number of people.
A pile or mass; a collection of things laid in a body, or thrown together so as to form an elevation.
examples: a heap of earth; a heap of stones

entries.meaning: A great number or large quantity of things.
examples: a vast heap, both of places of scripture and quotations

entries.meaning: (computing) A data structure consisting of trees in which each node is greater than all its children.

examples: You should move these structures from the stack to the heap to avoid a potential stack overflow.
Chuffy: It's on a knife edge at the moment, Bertie. If he can get planning permission, old Stoker's going to take this heap off my hands in return for vast amounts of oof.

verbs.description: heap (third-person singular simple present heaps, present participle heaping, simple past and past participle heaped)

examples: He heaped the laundry upon the bed and began folding.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form or round into a heap, as in measuring.
examples: Cry a reward, to him who shall first bring  News of that vanished Arabian,  A full-heap‚Äôd helmet of the purest gold.
They heaped praise upon their newest hero.
